BIOS313
Notes
New module as part of programme review. Due to commence September 2026

Overview

Overview
This module aims to build upon the pharmacology principles students will have already covered to highlight how, in a range of clinical settings, drugs work for particular conditions including infectious diseases, neurology, oncology and cardiovascular disease. The module enable students to develop an understanding of a range of different drug modalities and their mechanisms of action. This will enable students to develop knowledge of clinical applications of drugs both clinically and from an industry perspective, widening access to professions in both sectors. This is a key 3rd module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures, seminars and workshops. Assessment will be in the form of a written report related to a data analysis task (40%) and a written exam (60%).
Educational Aims
This modules aims to :
Develop students understanding of the key pathology of diseases and how drugs work to treat them.

Provide students with an understanding how drug discoveries translate to clinical utility.

Enable students to explain why some drug resistance develops and understand strategies to overcome it.

Develop students ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding, to solve complex problems in pharmacology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The translation of therapeutics to clinical use for the benefit of patients is a key milestone in the development of a drug. This module is designed to give students a deeper understanding of diseases and conditions which affect a range of organ systems and how drugs work to treat them. It will build upon pharmacology principles to highlight how, in a range of clinical settings, drugs work for particular conditions including infectious diseases, neurology, oncology and cardiovascular disease. Students will learn about the underlying disease/ condition, therapeutic targets, drugs and their mechanism of action and how they benefit the patient. They will learn aspects of clinical pharmacology, including personalised methodologies, and to assess patient data via case studies incorporating real-world clinical data. Teaching is via a series of formal lectures, interactive workshops and seminars. The module will be assessed by a report of a data analysis task related to the different topics and a written exam assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Topics covered will include::

TOPIC 1: Infectious disease pharmacology (To include drug targets of diseases, drug resistance, vaccines)
• Antivirals (HIV/ hepatitis)
• Antibacterials
• Anti-fungals
• Anti-TB/ anti-TB
• Anti-malarials

TOPIC 2: Cardiovascular/ Respiratory pharmacology
• Fundamental Cardiovascular Physiology
• Arrhythmics/ Vascular Pharmacology
• Atherosclerosis/ lipid lowering/Clin Pharm heart failure/ ischaemic heart disease/ hypertension
• Lung Function/ Asthma

TOPIC 3: Neuropharmacology
• Drug action at the synapse
• Epilepsy
• Neurodegenerative Diseases
• Psychiatry disorders

TOPIC 4: Cancer Pharmacology
• Pathophysiology and hallmarks of Cancer (Including Somatic Mutations/ Stratification/ Companion Diagnostics)
• Classical Chemotherapy and anti-hormonal therapy
• Molecular targeted therapy
• Immunotherapy/ vaccines/ biologics
• Drug Resistance/ drug toxicity
• Drug superiority/ inferiority assessment of new drugs

TOPIC 5: Clinical Pharmacology of other notable disease areas:
• Gastroenterology / Diabetes
• Auto-Immune Diseases
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Workshops: These will allow key topics to be recapped and to provide important case studies which encapsulate the key principle covered on lectures.

Seminars: External speakers (clinical and industry) will be invited to provide examples of translational pharmacology from their own perspective.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. By teaching students key principles in drug action and clinical application, this module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:
Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

The first assessment consists of writing a report of a data analysis task related to the different topics. It is worth 40% of the module.
The second assessment consists of an essay-style assessment which critically appraises the literature on topics covered in the module. It is worth 60% of the module. Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark). This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Assess the principles of pharmacological agents used in the treatment of a range of diseases.
 LO2 Appraise the underlying pathology of diseases and the mechanism of action of therapies used to treat them.
 LO3 Apply an understanding of drug resistance and drug toxicity to select appropriate therapeutic strategies to overcome them.
 LO4 Critically appraise information on the mechanism of action of different drugs and drug modalities and how they are used therapeutically.
 LO5 Critically evaluate data pertaining to efficacy and/or safety of drug therapies used treat a range of conditions.

BIOS313
Notes
New module as part of programme review. Due to commence September 2026

Overview

Overview
This module aims to build upon the pharmacology principles students will have already covered to highlight how, in a range of clinical settings, drugs work for particular conditions including infectious diseases, neurology, oncology and cardiovascular disease. The module enable students to develop an understanding of a range of different drug modalities and their mechanisms of action. This will enable students to develop knowledge of clinical applications of drugs both clinically and from an industry perspective, widening access to professions in both sectors. This is a key 3rd module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures, seminars and workshops. Assessment will be in the form of a written report related to a data analysis task (40%) and a written exam (60%).
Educational Aims
This modules aims to :
Develop students understanding of the key pathology of diseases and how drugs work to treat them.

Provide students with an understanding how drug discoveries translate to clinical utility.

Enable students to explain why some drug resistance develops and understand strategies to overcome it.

Develop students ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding, to solve complex problems in pharmacology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The translation of therapeutics to clinical use for the benefit of patients is a key milestone in the development of a drug. This module is designed to give students a deeper understanding of diseases and conditions which affect a range of organ systems and how drugs work to treat them. It will build upon pharmacology principles to highlight how, in a range of clinical settings, drugs work for particular conditions including infectious diseases, neurology, oncology and cardiovascular disease. Students will learn about the underlying disease/ condition, therapeutic targets, drugs and their mechanism of action and how they benefit the patient. They will learn aspects of clinical pharmacology, including personalised methodologies, and to assess patient data via case studies incorporating real-world clinical data. Teaching is via a series of formal lectures, interactive workshops and seminars. The module will be assessed by a report of a data analysis task related to the different topics and a written exam assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Topics covered will include::

TOPIC 1: Infectious disease pharmacology (To include drug targets of diseases, drug resistance, vaccines)
• Antivirals (HIV/ hepatitis)
• Antibacterials
• Anti-fungals
• Anti-TB/ anti-TB
• Anti-malarials

TOPIC 2: Cardiovascular/ Respiratory pharmacology
• Fundamental Cardiovascular Physiology
• Arrhythmics/ Vascular Pharmacology
• Atherosclerosis/ lipid lowering/Clin Pharm heart failure/ ischaemic heart disease/ hypertension
• Lung Function/ Asthma

TOPIC 3: Neuropharmacology
• Drug action at the synapse
• Epilepsy
• Neurodegenerative Diseases
• Psychiatry disorders

TOPIC 4: Cancer Pharmacology
• Pathophysiology and hallmarks of Cancer (Including Somatic Mutations/ Stratification/ Companion Diagnostics)
• Classical Chemotherapy and anti-hormonal therapy
• Molecular targeted therapy
• Immunotherapy/ vaccines/ biologics
• Drug Resistance/ drug toxicity
• Drug superiority/ inferiority assessment of new drugs

TOPIC 5: Clinical Pharmacology of other notable disease areas:
• Gastroenterology / Diabetes
• Auto-Immune Diseases
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Workshops: These will allow key topics to be recapped and to provide important case studies which encapsulate the key principle covered on lectures.

Seminars: External speakers (clinical and industry) will be invited to provide examples of translational pharmacology from their own perspective.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. By teaching students key principles in drug action and clinical application, this module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:
Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

The first assessment consists of writing a report of a data analysis task related to the different topics. It is worth 40% of the module.
The second assessment consists of an essay-style assessment which critically appraises the literature on topics covered in the module. It is worth 60% of the module. Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark). This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO4 Critically appraise information on the mechanism of action of different drugs and drug modalities and how they are used therapeutically.
 LO5 Critically evaluate data pertaining to efficacy and/or safety of drug therapies used treat a range of conditions.

Notes
New module as part of programme review. Due to commence September 2026

Overview

Overview
This module aims to build upon the pharmacology principles students will have already covered to highlight how, in a range of clinical settings, drugs work for particular conditions including infectious diseases, neurology, oncology and cardiovascular disease. The module enable students to develop an understanding of a range of different drug modalities and their mechanisms of action. This will enable students to develop knowledge of clinical applications of drugs both clinically and from an industry perspective, widening access to professions in both sectors. This is a key 3rd module which is mandatory for BSc Pharmacology and optional for other programmes. The module includes research-connected teaching in the form of lectures, seminars and workshops. Assessment will be in the form of a written report related to a data analysis task (40%) and a written exam (60%).
Educational Aims
This modules aims to :
Develop students understanding of the key pathology of diseases and how drugs work to treat them.

Provide students with an understanding how drug discoveries translate to clinical utility.

Enable students to explain why some drug resistance develops and understand strategies to overcome it.

Develop students ability to apply, critically evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding, to solve complex problems in pharmacology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The translation of therapeutics to clinical use for the benefit of patients is a key milestone in the development of a drug. This module is designed to give students a deeper understanding of diseases and conditions which affect a range of organ systems and how drugs work to treat them. It will build upon pharmacology principles to highlight how, in a range of clinical settings, drugs work for particular conditions including infectious diseases, neurology, oncology and cardiovascular disease. Students will learn about the underlying disease/ condition, therapeutic targets, drugs and their mechanism of action and how they benefit the patient. They will learn aspects of clinical pharmacology, including personalised methodologies, and to assess patient data via case studies incorporating real-world clinical data. Teaching is via a series of formal lectures, interactive workshops and seminars. The module will be assessed by a report of a data analysis task related to the different topics and a written exam assessment.
Outline Syllabus
Topics covered will include::

TOPIC 1: Infectious disease pharmacology (To include drug targets of diseases, drug resistance, vaccines)
• Antivirals (HIV/ hepatitis)
• Antibacterials
• Anti-fungals
• Anti-TB/ anti-TB
• Anti-malarials

TOPIC 2: Cardiovascular/ Respiratory pharmacology
• Fundamental Cardiovascular Physiology
• Arrhythmics/ Vascular Pharmacology
• Atherosclerosis/ lipid lowering/Clin Pharm heart failure/ ischaemic heart disease/ hypertension
• Lung Function/ Asthma

TOPIC 3: Neuropharmacology
• Drug action at the synapse
• Epilepsy
• Neurodegenerative Diseases
• Psychiatry disorders

TOPIC 4: Cancer Pharmacology
• Pathophysiology and hallmarks of Cancer (Including Somatic Mutations/ Stratification/ Companion Diagnostics)
• Classical Chemotherapy and anti-hormonal therapy
• Molecular targeted therapy
• Immunotherapy/ vaccines/ biologics
• Drug Resistance/ drug toxicity
• Drug superiority/ inferiority assessment of new drugs

TOPIC 5: Clinical Pharmacology of other notable disease areas:
• Gastroenterology / Diabetes
• Auto-Immune Diseases
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Lectures: These will cover core curriculum topics. Research focus lectures will examine areas of current interest in more detail or employability issues and opportunities related to the topic area.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Workshops: These will allow key topics to be recapped and to provide important case studies which encapsulate the key principle covered on lectures.

Seminars: External speakers (clinical and industry) will be invited to provide examples of translational pharmacology from their own perspective.

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool curriculum framework and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. By teaching students key principles in drug action and clinical application, this module contributes to a programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences – employability. For example, digital fluency is taught by data analysis and the use of online platforms. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching as experts in their field teach the module.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessments:
Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

The first assessment consists of writing a report of a data analysis task related to the different topics. It is worth 40% of the module.
The second assessment consists of an essay-style assessment which critically appraises the literature on topics covered in the module. It is worth 60% of the module. Both assessments are authentic in that they require a meaningful and integrated application of students’ knowledge and understanding of the module topics. Scientific writing is an authentic skill required for further study or employment.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark). This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Assess the principles of pharmacological agents used in the treatment of a range of diseases.
 LO2 Appraise the underlying pathology of diseases and the mechanism of action of therapies used to treat them.
 LO3 Apply an understanding of drug resistance and drug toxicity to select appropriate therapeutic strategies to overcome them.
 LO4 Critically appraise information on the mechanism of action of different drugs and drug modalities and how they are used therapeutically.
 LO5 Critically evaluate data pertaining to efficacy and/or safety of drug therapies used treat a range of conditions.

Skills
